A 'neologism' (; ) is a newly coined term, word, or phrase, that may be in the
process of entering common use, but has not yet been accepted into mainstream
language. Neologisms are often directly attributable to a specific
person, publication, period, or event. 'ÎÎµÎ¿Î»ÎµÎ¾Î¯Î±' (Greek: a "new word", or the
act of creating a new word) is a synonym for it. The term neologism is first
attested in English in 1772, borrowed from French nÃ©ologisme
(1734). [[Oxford English Dictionary]], draft revision Dec. 2009,
[http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/00322941 s.v.]

In psychiatry, the term neologism is used to describe the use of words that have
meaning only to the person who uses them, independent of their common
meaning. G E Berrios (2009) Neologisms. History of Psychiatry 20: 480-
496 This tendency is considered normal in children, but in adults can be a
symptom of psychopathy "Most of us are able to combine ideas so that they
are consistent with some underlying theme, but psychopaths seem to have
difficulty doing so. This helps to explain the wild inconsistencies and
contradictions that frequently characterize their speech. It may also account
for their use of neologisms (combining the basic components of words --
syllables -- in ways that seem logical to them but inappropriate to others)."
Robert D. Hare (1999), Without Conscience: The Disturbing World of the
Psychopaths Among Us. Guildford Press, [http://books.google.com/books?id=xfIEVt-
zj52YC&lpg=PP1&vq=neologism&dq=%22not%20a%20serial%20killer%20now%2C%20but%20yo-
u've%20serially%20killed%3F%22&pg=PA137#v=onepage&q=neologisms&f=false p.
137] or a thought disorder (indicative of a psychotic mental illness, such
as schizophrenia). P. J. McKenna, Schizophrenia and Related Syndromes. Page
363. People with autism also may create
neologisms. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1864825 Neologisms and
idiosyncratic language in autistic speakers]. J Autism Dev Disord. 1991 Jun;21(2):109-
30. Additionally, use of neologisms may be related to aphasia acquired
after brain damage resulting from a stroke or head injury. B Butterworth,
Hesitation and the production of verbal paraphasias and neologisms in jargon
aphasia. Brain Lang, 1979

In theology, a neologism is a relatively new doctrine (for example,
Transcendentalism). In this sense, a neologist is one who proposes either a new
doctrine or a new interpretation of source material such as religious
texts. Wood, J., "The Nuttall EncyclopÃ¦dia: Being a Concise and
Comprehensive Dictionary of General Knowledge" (1907), [http://www.fromoldbooks.org/Wood-
NuttallEncyclopaedia/n/neology.html]

A 'stunt word' is a neologism created to produce a special effect, or to attract
attention. Encyclopedic Graded Grammar, Vol 2, ISBN 1-4357-4069-6,
[http://books.google.com/books?id=2nLSaQKKHQ0C&pg=PA925&dq=%22stunt+word%22&lr=
p. 925] Examples are gloatation, titterosity, scrumtrulescent,
malamanteau, and [[truthiness]]. Some stunt words are portmanteau words, and
many are also based on malapropisms. The Oxford Companion to the English
Language, Oxford University Press (1992), p. 991 (ISBN 0-19-214183-
X) Fifty Years Among the New Words: A Dictionary of neologisms,
Cambridge University Press 1993, Edited by John Algeo, p. 231 (ref. "smuttery")
(ISBN 978-0521449717)
